questions.text: An 85-year-old man presented with headache and left-sided weakness. NCCT of the head showed a right frontal lobar intracerebral hemorrhage; results from CT angiography of the brain were normal. The patient takes warfarin for atrial fibrillation, and his international normalized ratio at presentation was 1.4. His medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and he also has dementia. What is the most likely cause of the hemorrhage?
questions.solution: Lobar hemorrhages in elderly patients are often secondary to cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Hypertension is the main risk factor for all intracerebral hemorrhages, but it usually affects deep penetrating vessels and causes hemorrhages in the basal ganglia, thalamus, brainstem, or cerebellum. Anticoagulant medications, such as warfarin, increase the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage for patients with cerebral amyloid angiopathy but are not the primary cause. An arteriovenous malformation would be unlikely given the normal findings with CT angiography of the brain.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man has had slowly progressive asymmetric weakness of distal and proximal muscles in all limbs over the past 3 years. He does not take any medications. He does not have any pain or other sensory symptoms. On examination, he has no rash. He has diffuse limb weakness that is most prominent in the finger flexor and quadriceps muscles. Muscle stretch reflexes are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This patient’s clinical syndrome is most consistent with inclusion body myositis. Supporting features include pro- gressive weakness in all limbs, lack of pain, and prominence of the flexor muscles. This patient’s presentation is not consistent with peripheral neuropathy, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or myasthenia gravis. Patients with peripheral neuropathy usually present with distal weakness and distal sensory changes that are typically symmetric and more severe in the legs than in the arms. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a degenerative disorder that affects the motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and the anterior horn cells and causes progressive, painless weakness that typically begins distally. Patients with myasthenia gravis classically present with diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, and dyspnea that are usually worse with repetitive contraction on examination or subjectively late in the day.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease had her first seizure. Upon arrival at the emergency department 15 minutes later, she is confused and the left side of her face twitches intermittently. She has not received sedating medications. Results are normal for ECG, blood glucose level, chemistry panel, and hematologic and toxicologic testing. Which of the following should be efficacious as the initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution: Nonconvulsive status epilepticus may cause an acute confusional state or stupor and coma, especially in the elderly. Patients may have subtle rhythmic motor activity in the limbs or face. Electroencephalography is a critical diagnostic tool because nonconvulsive status epilepticus must be treated as quickly and as vigorously as convulsive status epilepticus. Initial therapy for status epilepticus should include IV lorazepam, IV diazepam, or IM midazolam.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with hepatitis C and chronic liver dysfunction has had 2 focal seizures with secondary generalization. Which of the following would be the best initial medication for this patient?
questions.solution: Benzodiazepines, carbamazepine, felbamate, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone, rufinamide, and valproic acid are primarily metabolized in the liver and should be avoided in patients with hepatic failure

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is evaluated for progressive gait difficulties, slurred speech, and upper extremity tremor over the past 2 years. During the past year he has had difficulties with performance at school, and increased irritability. Examination shows fluctuating level of attention, masked faces, broad-based and shuffling gait, rigidity, upper extremity tremor at rest with marked worsening with voluntary movements, and mild dysmetria. Motor strength, sensory examination findings, and reflexes are normal. What is the first diagnosis to be considered in this patient?
questions.solution: Wilson disease should always be considered for any young patient with a movement disorder with or without cognitive and behavioral symptoms. Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutations of the gene encoding the copper transporter ATP7. Typical findings include the presence of copper deposits around the cornea, reduced plasma ceruloplasmin, and reduced plasma and urinary copper levels. Whereas dopa-responsive dystonia and juvenile-onset Parkinson disease should be considered in young patients with dystonia or parkinsonism, the cognitive and behavioral manifestations and cerebellar signs in this patient are not consistent with these disorders. Friedreich ataxia is characterized by not only severe ataxia but also proprioceptive sensory loss, areflexia, and bilateral Babinski sign, which are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive gait difficulties and falls in the past 10 months. The initial diagnosis was Parkinson disease, and she received levodopa therapy with mild improvement of the symptoms for 3 months, but then she had a lack of response and orthostatic dizziness. Urinary urgency developed and, more recently, urinary incontinence. She denies any cognitive symptoms. Neurologic examination showed normal mental status, including attention and construction abilities, nor- mal eye movements, bradykinesia, rigidity, severe gait instability with a tendency to fall backward, mild dysmetria, and jerky movements of the upper limbs. Motor strength, sensory examination, and reflexes were normal. Blood pressure in the supine position was 150/90 mm Hg with a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. Standing blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg with a heart rate of 84 beats per minute. Polysomnography showed absent muscle atonia during REM sleep and laryngeal stridor. Ultrasonography of the bladder showed a post-void residual volume of 300 mL. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The presence of levodopa-resistant parkinsonism, falls in the early course of the disease, mild dysmetria (suggestive of cerebellar dysfunction), jerky limb movements (myoclonus), orthostatic hypotension, urinary retention, and laryngeal stridor are all consistent with multiple system atrophy. Dementia with Lewy bodies would be less likely given the lack of attention and constructional impairment and no history of cognitive fluctuations or visual hallucinations. Progressive supranuclear palsy and corticobasal degeneration would be unlikely given the prominent autonomic features and the presence of REM sleep behavior disorder. In addition, the lack of impaired vertical eye movements would argue against progressive supranuclear palsy, and the lack of asymmetric apraxia, dystonia, or cortical sensory loss would argue against cortico- basal degeneration.

choices.text: Transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is admitted from the emergency department with upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis but felt well until early this morning when he had hematemesis. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy in the emergency department showed large esophageal varices, which were ligated. He currently feels weak but has had no other complaints. Physical examination findings include the following: blood pressure 120/60 mm Hg, heart rate 82 beats per minute, alert and oriented, splenomegaly, and no ascites or edema. Laboratory study results are as follows: hemoglobin 10.2 g/L, platelet count 65X109/L, aspartate aminotransferase 84 U/L, alanine aminotransferase 75 U/L, total bilirubin 1.2 mg/dL, albumin 3.0 g/dL, and international normalized ratio 1.2. Abdominal ultrasonography shows no liver mass, a patent portal vein, splenomegaly, and no ascites. Which of the following would you advise now?
questions.solution: Patients with cirrhosis who are admitted with gastro- intestinal tract bleeding should receive prophylactic antibiotics even if there is no ascites. Oral norfloxacin is probably sufficient, although a recent trial suggested that a third-generation cephalosporin may be more effective if there is a high prevalence of quinolone resistance. Much of the recent reduction in mortality related to variceal bleed- ing is probably due to the increasing use of prophylactic antibiotics in patients with cirrhosis and gastrointestinal tract bleeding. Transjugular intrahepatic portal systemic shunt is not necessary unless bleeding cannot be controlled with endoscopy or medical therapy. Although the hemo- globin level should be carefully monitored, the patient is hemodynamically stable and does not need transfusion now. Overtransfusion, when hemoglobin is greater than 8 to 9 g/dL, can precipitate recurrence of bleeding and fluid overload. Fresh frozen plasma is also not necessary since the INR is relatively normal. A decision about pegylated interferon and ribavirin treatment of hepatitis C should be deferred until the patient has recovered from this bleeding episode.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a structure involved in the formation of new memories within the circuit of Papez?
questions.solution: Injury to any structures within the circuit of Papez will interrupt formation of new memories. The mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus is not part of the circuit of Papez. The circuit of Papez is: entorhinal cortex → hippocampus → fornix → mammillary bodies → anterior nucleus of thalamus → cingulate gyrus → entorhinal cortex → hippocampus.

choices.text: Vancomycin 0.5 gr every 6 hours and ampicillin 2 gr every 4 hours
Cefotaxime 2 gr every 4 hours and vancomycin 0.5 gr every 6 hours
Vancomycin 0.5 gr every 6 hours and ceftazidine 2 gr every 8 hours

questions.text: What is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy for the treatment of hospital-acquired meningitis in a 55-year-old man with severe neutropenia?
questions.solution: In hospital-acquired meningitis and particularly meningitis following neuro- surgical procedures, staphylococci and gram- negative organisms (including P. aeruginosa), are the most common etiological organisms. In these patients, empiric therapy should include a combination of vancomycin and ceftazidime. Ceftazidime should be substituted for ceftriaxone or cefotaxime in neurosurgical patients and in neutropenic patients, as P. aeruginosa may be the meningeal pathogen, and ceftazidime is the only cephalosporin with sufficient activity against P. aeruginosa in the CNS

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of pain and swelling to the distal interphalangeal joints of the right index and left ring fingers and diffuse swelling and pain of the right great toe. He has had an intermittent rash to the scalp and elbows since he was a teenager, which is not currently present. Laboratory investigation shows a normal complete blood cell count and blood chemistry panel. Sedimentation rate is increased at 40 mm/hour and C-reactive protein is increased at 10.7 mg/L. What is the most likely diagnosis for this man?
questions.solution: Asymmetrical joint involvement with the DIP joints affected would be most suggestive of psoriatic arthritis. The diffuse swelling of the great toe is suggestive of dactylitis, which is a characteristic of spondyloarthropathies and is not seen with any of the other listed conditions. The rash of psoriasis may not always be present at the time of diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. The long duration of symptoms and involvement of the upper extremities is atypical for gout. Lyme disease arthri- tis most often presents as monoarthritis involving the knee; in cases where there is oligoarticular involvement, the DIP joints are not usually affected. The asymmetrical joint involvement and involvement of the DIP joints is unusual for rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for evaluation of cough, which has been persistent over the past 6 months. He is a lifelong non- smoker, and his past medical history is notable only for hypertension, managed with amlodipine and lisinopril. He reports no fever, rash, or joint symptoms. Radiography of the chest shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and upper lobe-predominant nodular pulmonary infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Sarcoidosis is the most likely consideration among the answer choices. Sarcoidosis is compatible with the history of cough in a lifelong nonsmoker in his fourth decade, and the radiographic findings of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and upper lobe–predominant infiltrates would be typical for stage II pulmonary sarcoidosis. IPF would be unlikely in someone so young (it usually affects persons older than 50 years), and the radiographic abnormalities of IPF typi- cally predominate in the lower lobes. Neither amlodipine nor lisinopril is associated with drug-induced ILD, and a patient with lisinopril-associated cough should not have abnormalities on chest imaging.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a history of an uncontrollable urge to move her legs, which occurs nightly while lying in bed. Stretching her legs and walking offer temporary symptomatic relief, although sleep initiation is affected. She provides a history of heavy menstrual periods. Neurologic examination findings are normal for the lower limbs, including motor strength, reflexes, and sensation to vibration, joint position, pinprick, and tempera- ture. What is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: The patient has a history that is consistent with restless legs syndrome. Of the answer choices provided, ferritin would be the most appropriate test, particularly in the context of heavy menstrual periods. The other tests are not appropriate under these circumstances, especially given the normal findings on neurologic examination

choices.text: Use of a 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitor

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a history of snoring, witnessed apneas, and excessive daytime sleepiness. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated at 152/90 mm Hg, his body mass index is 38 kg/m , his neck circumference is 44 cm, and he has a crowded oropharynx. What is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: The patient has a history and examination findings that sug- gest obstructive sleep apnea. Therefore, of the answers provided, HSAT would be the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis. Overnight oximetry may be used as a screening tool but is neither sensitive enough to rule out the diagnosis nor specific enough to confirm it. The other 2 tests are not used to make a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who has never smoked presents to the emergency department with acute-onset chest pain and short- ness of breath. Chest radiography shows a right-sided pneumo- thorax. After a chest tube is placed, computed tomography (CT) of the chest shows well-defined cysts scattered diffusely through- out both lungs without associated nodules or interstitial fibrosis. What is the best next step in treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: The patient most likely has lymphangioleiomyomatosis , a cystic lung disease that affects women of childbearing age who often present with spontaneous pneumothorax. The CT findings are classic for LAM: The dominant feature is well-defined pulmonary cysts that are diffusely distributed throughout both lungs without associated nodules or intersti-tial fibrosis. Sirolimus is the first-line medical therapy for stabilization of LAM. Tamoxifen and other treatments directed at hormonal manipulation have little evidence to support their use, and are not recommended for the treatment of LAM. Prednisone and methotrexate are not used for LAM.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with end-stage liver disease (cirrhosis) from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis presents with dyspnea and a large right-sided pleural effusion. This is his third presentation with a large right-sided effusion in the past 6 months. On examination, the patient has tense ascites, spider nevi, and gynecomastia. On thoracentesis, he again has a pale-yellow, clear fluid with pH 7.4, glucose 100 mg/dL, protein 1.2 g/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase 60 U/L. Lipid analysis results are normal. On a previous workup, the patient had a normal echocardiogram, normal renal function, and normal thyrotropin level. What is the likely cause of this patient's effusion?
questions.solution: The presentation is consistent with hepatic hydrothorax (recurrent large transudative pleural effusions in a patient with cirrhosis and no alternative explanation). Hepatic hydrothorax occurs predominantly on the right side and is transudative. Treatment is focused on controlling the ascites, which can become an intractable problem. The normal echocardiogram excludes congestive heart failure. Hypoalbuminemia-related effusions are typically bilateral with associated anasarca. Chylothorax is unlikely given the normal results from lipid analysis of the pleural fluid.

choices.text: Microcytosis with high transferrin level, low transferrin saturation, and low ferritin level
Normocytic anemia with low transferrin level and low transferrin saturation
Macrocytosis with low transferrin level and low transferrin saturation
Normocytic anemia with low transferrin level, high transferrin saturation, and high ferritin level

questions.text: A patient has stage 4 chronic kidney disease and anemia, with a hemoglobin value of 10 mg/dL. What laboratory findings are expected in anemia of CKD?
questions.solution: Anemia of chronic disease is usually a normocytic anemia associated with low transferrin level and low transferrin saturation. Iron deficiency anemia is associated with microcytosis, high transferrin level, low transferrin saturation, and low ferritin. Macrocytosis is not a common feature of CKD but is often associated with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. Option d is incorrect because the anemia of CKD is associated with low transferrin saturation rather than high transferrin saturation. Ferritin levels are not reliable in patients with CKD because ferritin is an acute phase protein.

choices.text: There is no change in the click with squatting or standing
A passive leg raise makes the click-murmur occur earlier
A squat maneuver makes the click-murmur occur later
The mitral regurgitant murmur does not change with positional maneuvers

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your office for evaluation. She appears healthy and is not limited by physical activity. She says that she has occasional chest pains that occur at rest, often with a change in position. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 76 beats per minute and regular. Auscultatory findings are a midsystolic click followed by a 2/6 apical systolic murmur that radiates to her axilla. Which of the following dynamic physical examination findings would confirm your suspicion of mitral valve prolapse?
questions.solution: This 30-year-old patient presents with atypical chest pain, which may be associated with mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse is essentially a mismatch of the left ventricular cavity size and the mitral valve leaflets, which are redundant. The classic bedside maneuver is the squat-to- stand maneuver; however, any maneuver that increases the left ventricular cavity size will delay midsystolic clicks and the mitral regurgitant murmur (Figure 2.A8). The Valsalva maneuver decreases venous return, which would result in a smaller left ventricle and thus an earlier mitral valve pro- lapse. A post extrasystolic beat (due to the compensatory pause), the passive leg raise, and squat (all would improve left ventricular filling) should actually delay mid-systolic clicks and murmur.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents to the hospital with new orthopnea and edema. His blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 96 beats per minute. He has clear lungs, a displaced cardiac apex with a third heart sound but no cardiac murmurs, and no lower extremity edema. Laboratory test results were as follows: hemoglobin 14 g/dL, sodium 137 mEq/L, potassium 4.4 mEq/L, and serum creatinine 1.7 mg/dL. Chest radiography shows pulmonary congestion with cardiomegaly. The ECG shows sinus rhythm, nonspecific ST-T changes, and frequent premature ventricular complexes . Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 20% and a dilated left ventricle. What should be the next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution: The patient has dilated cardiomyopathy. The most com- mon cause of dilated cardiomyopathy, especially in a person with atherosclerotic risk factors, is coronary artery disease. The most appropriate next step for this patient would be to perform coronary angiography, the best diagnostic test in this circumstance. Stress testing may have false-positive or false-negative results in patients with dilated cardio- myopathy. Endomyocardial biopsy should not be routinely performed in the evaluation of patients with heart failure. Holter monitoring is useful in detecting the PVC burden over a 24-hour period, and if the PVC burden were especially high, it could be implicated as a rare cause of heart failure. However, Holter minitoring would not be the next step in evaluation and should not be performed without initiating medical therapy because indicated medical treatment (eg, β-blockers) can attenuate PVCs. Sleep apnea could be a frequent accompaniment of decompensated heart failure, but a sleep study should be performed only after patients are optimally treated.

questions.text: The device shown has its utility in the management of ?
questions.solution: The device shown is an oxygen concentrator for delivering long term oxygen therapy (LTOT). Room air is entrained into the machine, and nitrogen is adsorbed by zeolite material, resulting in high-concentration oxygen. Concentrators are typically able to deliver concentrations between 50% and 95% at a flow rate of up to 5 l/min. Long-term oxygen therapy should be prescribed for patients in respiratory failure.

questions.text: C-TB, the next generation skin test for tuberculosis uses which antigen ?
questions.solution: C-Tb is a highly specific skin test for the diagnosis of LTBIlk designed to address some of the drawbacks of TST and IGRAs . C-Tb is applied and read in the same way as TST, but is based on the antigens ESAT-6 and CFP-10 that are also included in the IGRAs. Due to high specificity, C-Tb uses a universal 5 mm cut-point induration irrespective of the status of BCG, HIV etc.

questions.text: DLCO is decreased in all the following except ?
questions.solution: Pulmonary hemorrhage is characterised by increased DLCO.

questions.text: Most effective therapy for type 2 brittle asthma is ?
questions.solution:
Brittle Asthma
Some patients show chaotic variations in lung function despite taking appropriate therapy. Some show a persistent pattern of variability and may require oral corticosteroids or, at times, continuous infusion of beta 2 -agonists (type I brittle asthma), whereas others have generally normal or near-normal lung function but precipitous, unpredictable falls in lung function that may result in death (type 2 brittle asthma). These latter patients are difficult to manage as they do not respond well to corticosteroids, and the worsening of asthma does not reverse well with inhaled bronchodilators. The most effective therapy is subcutaneous epinephrine, which suggests that the worsening is likely to be a localized airway anaphylactic reaction with edema.

choices.text: Results can be available in 24 hours
BCG vaccination causes false positive result
Negative test does not rule exclude LTBI or TB disease

questions.text: False statement regarding Interferon gamma release assay ?
questions.solution: Usually BCG vaccination status does not interfere with IGRA.

choices.text: Atrial septal defect without Eisenmenger syndrome
Prior peripartum cardiomyopathy with a current ejection fraction of 65%

questions.text: Which of the following cardiovascular conditions is a contraindication to pregnancy?
questions.solution: Most cardiovascular conditions can be managed safely in pregnancy, although these pregnancies are often considered high risk. The conditions that are considered to be contraindications to pregnancy are idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension and Eisenmenger syndrome (congenital heart disease resulting in pulmonary hypertension with right-to-left shunting). In these cases, it is typically recommended to terminate the pregnancy because there is a high risk of maternal and fetal death. Peripartum cardiomyopathy can recur in subsequent pregnancies, and it is recommended that individuals with an abnormal ejection fraction avoid further pregnancies. Approximately 15% of individuals with Marfan syndrome will have a major cardiovascular complication in pregnancy, although the condition is not considered a contraindication to pregnancy. An aortic root diameter of less than 40 mm is generally associated with the best outcomes in pregnancy. The valvular heart disease with the greatest risk in pregnancy is mitral stenosis. There is an increased risk of pulmonary edema, and pulmonary hypertension is a common long-term consequence of mitral stenosis. However, aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation, and mitral regurgitation are typically well tolerated. Congenital heart disease in the mother is associated with an increased risk of congenital heart disease in the offspring, but atrial and ventricular septal defects are usually well tolerated in pregnancy as long as there is no evidence of Eisenmenger syndrome.

questions.text: Duration of continuation phase for drug sensitive pulmonary tuberculosis ?
questions.solution: Intensive phase is for 2 months and continuation phase for 4 months.

choices.text: Demonstration of absent cranial nerve reflexes
Demonstration of fixed and dilated pupils

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is evaluated after a large subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm. There is concern that the patient has brain death. What test is most commonly used to diagnose brain death in this situation?
questions.solution: Three essential elements should be demonstrated for the diagnosis of brain death. First, the patient should widespread cortical damage with complete absence of response to all external stimuli. Second, the patient should have no evidence of brainstem function with loss of oculovestibular and corneal reflexes and absent pupillary reaction to light. Finally, there should be no evidence of medullary activity manifested by apnea.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Rofumilast ?
questions.solution: The selective phosphodiesterase 4 (PDE4) inhibitor roflumilast has been demonstrated to reduce exacerbation frequency in patients with severe COPD, chronic bronchitis, and a prior history of exacerbations; its effects on airflow obstruction and symptoms are modest

questions.text: In a COPD patient, FEV1 50-80% of predicted falls under what severity of airflow limitation ?

A 59-year-old patient is referred following urgent assessment by the stroke team. He has attended with sudden onset visual disturbance, followed by decreased GCS and left-sided hemiparesis. CT has demonstrated a right-sided middle cerebral artery thrombus. He was unfortunately outside the window for thrombolysis, but has been managed on the stroke unit with antiplatelet therapy. It is now 48 hours post- event and his GCS has continued to deteriorate, from 12 yesterday to 7 today. Which of the following options is most likely to reduce mortality?
questions.solution: Malignant cerebral artery syndrome carries a mortality of 80%. This is often due to increasing cerebral oedema refractory to medical treatment, leading to eventual herniation and death. Rising intracranial pressure as a result of stroke is theoretically amenable to surgical intervention, in the same way as traumatic brain injury.

choices.text: Furosemide infusion titrated to a urine output of 0.5ml/kg/hr.
Human albumin infusion at a rate of 20g/day.
Intravenous terlipressin at a dose of 0.5-2mg 4-6-hourly.

questions.text: In the management of suspected hepatorenal syndrome in the critically ill patient, which of the following therapeutic options is likely to be most efficacious?
questions.solution: Hepatorenal syndrome is defined as a functional renal failure in patients with liver disease and portal hypertension. It can be segregated into Type 1, caused by splanchnic vasodilatation and a reduction in cardiac output leading to profound renal vasoconstriction, or Type 2, where slow incipient renal failure leads to progressive accumulation of refractory ascites. It is essentially a diagnosis of exclusion following assessment for the multiple other causes of renal failure in the critically ill patient with cirrhosis. I Treatment is focused on improving renal blood flow via intravascular volume repletion and vasoconstriction. Albumin is the preferred choice for volume repletion in these patients, but usually commenced at a higher loading dose of 1g/kg up to 100g/day. Terlipressin is likely to be the most efficacious agent, due to splanchnic vasoconstriction and redirection of central blood flow to vital organs.. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPSS) has a role but is a therapy with limited supporting evidence. Furosemide infusion is likely to exacerbate the situation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with complaints of new-onset headache. She is fatigued and has lost about 2.3 kg over the past month. The patient describes daily bitemporal headaches. On further questioning, she describes morning stiffness lasting about 1 hour and aching in the shoulders and hips. She reports transient loss of vision in her right eye for about 30 minutes yesterday before her vision returned. Physical examination findings are unremarkable for her age. Initial laboratory studies show a mild normochromic anemia and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 101 mm/h. Which would be the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: In a patient of this age with a new onset of headache, anemia, and highly elevated ESR, giant cell arteritis would be the number one consideration. Temporal artery biopsy would be appropriate, but with the high degree of suspicion for GCA (because of the loss of vision), prednisone therapy should begin without waiting for the biopsy results. The appropriate dose of prednisone for GCA is 1 mg/kg daily. Lower doses are appropriate for polymyalgia rheumatica. A CT scan of the head would not be helpful for a patient with suspected GCA.

questions.text: A Chronic Kidney disease patient was brought to the casualty with worsening of breathlessness along with decreased urine output. ECG showed the following finding. Which of the following drugs should be given for this patient urgently :
questions.solution: This ECG finding of sine wave pattern in a CKD patient with probable recent worsening is most likely associated with hyperkalemia. Hence calcium gluconate has to be given urgently.

questions.text: From the general examination finding of this patient 40 year old female admitted in the medicine ward, what is the likely nutrient deficiency that the patient is having ?
questions.solution:
The patient in question is having perifollicular hemorrhages and cork screw shaped hair suggestive of Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency). Dear students, have a look at the following images showing the mucocutaneous manifestations of scurvy.


Physical examination of the legs in the above image is showing perifollicular petechiae, follicular hyperkeratosis, and corkscrew hairs in addition to red and blue ecchymoses on both ankles (Panels A and B). Examination of the oral mucosa showed gingival bleeding (Panel C). A skin-biopsy from the lesion on one leg shows a corkscrew hair (Panel D, arrow) with perifollicular hemorrhage

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient done as a part of routine work up before a major surgery. Seeing the abnormality, a medicine consultation is done to comment on this ECG. What is the likely explanation the medicine consultant has for the ECG finding ?
questions.solution: The ECG finding is that of Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). LBBB may be a finding in ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and hypertensive heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the findings does not favor pre-renal azotemia ?
questions.solution: In pre-renal azotemia, Fractional excretion of sodium is <1%

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient who presented with acute onset breathless to the emergency. What is the confirmatory test for the diagnosis of the patient ?
questions.solution:
The ECG is showing electrical alternans.
Electrical alternans, i.e. alternating QRS voltage, is a specific but insensitive ECG finding of a large pericardial effusion with tamponade. It is caused by mechanical anterior–posterior swinging of the heart in the large fluid. Echo will help to confirm the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

choices.text: MRI of the brain with contrast

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department with leg weakness, falls, and numbness, which have progressively worsened over the last week. She has been unable to control her bladder and had several episodes of incontinence. Her neurological examination reveals nearly flaccid paralysis of her legs and loss of sensation in her legs to all modalities. She has sensation loss to vibration and pin prick in her hands, and strength is mildly reduced. Her MRI is shown. Which of the following tests would uncover the diagnosis?
questions.solution: This patient presents with a severe transverse myelitis as evidenced by lower extremity paralysis and sensory loss to all modalities. MRIs show a longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM), spanning ≥3 spinal levels. LETM should point toward the diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica (NMO), and frequently aquaporin-4 antibodies are found in these patients. Oligoclonal bands can point toward a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS), which is possible, but myelitis in MS is usually a small segment or partial segment of the cord, not a longitudinally extensive lesion

questions.text: The below Chest Xray is that of a 58 year old chronic alcoholic who is admitted in the medicine ICU as a case of pneumonia. What is the likely causative organism ?
questions.solution: The X-ray shows the Bulging fissure sign. The bulging fissure sign refers to lobar consolidation where the affected portion of the lung is expanded causing displacement of the adjacent fissure.This is often associated with klebsiella pneumonia.

questions.text: The below is the diagrammatic representation of the breathing pattern of a patient admitted in the medicine ICU with an acute onset breathlessness following chest pain. What is the pattern of respiration here ?
questions.solution: This is the classical Cheyne Stokes respiration. Its also referred to as waxing and waning type of respiration. It is seen in acute LVF, raised ICT and Narcotic poisoning. The patient in question is probably having acute left ventricular failure following an acute coronary event.

questions.text: The following image is the Diffusion weighted MRI sequence of a patient who was admitted in the neurology ICU following a stroke. What is the likely finding in this patient ?
questions.solution: The Diffusion sequence is showing hyperintensity in the region of left occipital lobe extending into the splenium of corpus callosum. This is the classical site of lesion producing pure alexia (alexia without agraphia)

questions.text: A 54 year old female presented with cough and dyspnea of 4 years duration. She has a past history of anterior uveitis. The physician also noticed the following general examination finding. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Skin involvement is eventually identified in over a third of patients with sarcoidosis. The classic cutaneous lesions include erythema nodosum, maculopapular lesions, hyper- and hypopigmentation, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. A specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks is referred to as lupus pernio and is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: The given ECG trace is that of a patient admitted in ICU. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The ECG finding of a positive deflection at the J point (negative in aVR and V1) with a dome or hump configuration is most frequently termed a J wave or Osborn wave. There is no definitive physiological cause for the deflection despite numerous postulates. Broad differential diagnosis of prominent Osborn waves including hypothermia; benign early repolarization; hypercalcaemia and the Brugada syndrome.

questions.text: The pulse tracing shown below is most likely that of a patient with :
questions.solution: Pulsus alternans (alternation of one strong and one weak beat without a change in the cycle length) occurs most commonly in left ventricular failure.

questions.text: Peg filgrastim is used for the treatment of :
questions.solution:
Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor (G-CSF)

  • Recombinant human G-CSF (Filgrastim) is a glycoprotein produced in E.coli.
  • Principal action of filgrastim is the stimulation of CFU-G to increase neutrophil production.
  • It also enhances the phagocytic and cytotoxic functions of neutrophils.
  • Pegylated recombinant G-CSF (Peg filgrastim) is generated by conjugation of a polyethylene glycol moiety to an N-terminal methionyl residue of 
  • Therapeutic indications include :
    -Afebrile neutropenic patients
    -Febrile neutropenic patients(especially in case of clinical
      deterioration from sepsis,pneumonia or fungal infection)
    -In bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cell transplantation
    -In acute myeloid leukemia
    -In myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Preventive indications include :
    - With the first cycle of chemotherapy (so called Primary CSF
       administration)
    - With subsequent cycles if febrile neutropenia has previously occurred
       (so called Secondary CSF administration)

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with memory loss over the last several months. He notes antecedent arthralgia, low-grade fevers, skin hyperpigmentation, and frequent diarrhea. On examination he has mild rigidity in his upper extremities, and concurrent slow pendular movements of the eyes and contraction of the masseter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Whipple disease is caused by an infection with Tropheryma whippelii, leading to low-grade fevers, arthralgia, diarrhea, muscle wasting, and hyperpigmentation. Neurological symptoms include extrapyramidal symptoms, limitations of vertical gaze, and characteristic oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pendular oscillations of the eyes with rhythmic contractions of the masticatory muscles). Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder resulting in accumulation of copper resulting in liver disease, movement disorders, and dementia. Fever and oculomasticatory myorhythmia are not present in Wilson disease. Neurosyphilis causes psychosis, agitation, aggression, dementia, multiple cranial neuropathies, and multifocal vasculitic infarcts. Early-onset Alzheimer disease presents with dementia but without systemic symptoms or movement disorders

questions.text: Which of the following neurologic disease can have the peripheral smear finding ?
questions.solution:
• The peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis. Neurological conditions that have acanthocytes in peripheral smear are :
  • Neuroacanthocytosis
  • Abetalipoproteinemia (Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome)

questions.text: Most common mutation found in MODY is :
questions.solution: Most common type of MODY is MODY 3

questions.text: Not true regarding Job's syndrome :
questions.solution:
Pattern of inheritance is Autosomal Dominant

Job’s syndrome

  • Also known as Hyper IgE syndrome
  • Autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance
  • Caused by mutation in the gene coding for the transcription factor STAT3
  • Characterised by recurrent skin and lung infections that can be complicated by pneumatoceles

questions.text: Acute monoarthritis of the left knee developed in a 62-year-old man receiving long-term hemodialysis. Joint aspiration analysis is negative with Gram staining, and polarization microscopy shows birefringent bipyramidal crystals that stain with alizarin red, indicative of calcium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Calcium oxalate arthropathy usually occurs in patients receiving long-term hemodialysis, and the bipyramidal crystals stain positive for calcium. Dialysis patients are also at increased risk for basic calcium phosphate disease, gout, and a septic joint. Negative Gram staining rules against a septic joint, and no urate crystals indicative of gout were seen. In basic calcium phosphate disease, crystals are seen only with electron microscopy, not with polarization microscopy.

choices.text: Allogeneic peripheral blood stem cell transplant
Active monitoring for disease progression and complications

questions.text: At her annual physical examination, an asymptomatic 68-year-old woman has lymphocytosis (32X109/L) with a normal hemoglobin level and platelet count. On examination, she has 1-cm lymphadenopathy in the cervical region and no palpable liver or spleen enlargement. A peripheral blood smear shows identically appearing mature lymphocytes with smudge cells. Flow cytometry of the peripheral blood lymphocytes shows a monoclonal B population with dim expression of ? light chain and CD20 that is positive for expression of CD5, CD19, and CD23. Which of the following is the best next step in her management?
questions.solution: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a clonal lymphoproliferative disorder of mature lymphocytes. The clinical diagnosis requires a B-lymphocyte count of more than 5 × 10 9 / L . Peripheral blood smears typically show smudge cells, which are lymphocytes that have broken during processing of the slide. The clinical course of CLL is chronic in most patients. For those with early-stage disease, standard practice is to withhold treatment until the disease is active or progressive. However, patients need to be monitored for disease progression, autoimmune complications, infections, and second cancers.
